revision.text:
'''African Writers Series''' ('''AWS''') is a series of books by [[List of African writers (by country)|African writers]] that has been published by [[Heinemann (book publisher)|Heinemann]] since 1962. The series has ensured an international voice to major African writers—including [[Chinua Achebe]], [[Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o]], [[Steve Biko]], [[Ama Ata Aidoo]], [[Nadine Gordimer]], [[Buchi Emecheta]], and [[Okot p'Bitek]]. The emphasis is on Anglophone Africa, although a number of volumes were translated into English from [[French language|French]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[Zulu language|Zulu]], [[Swahili language|Swahili]], [[Acoli language|Acoli]], [[Sesotho]], [[Afrikaans]], [[Luganda]] and [[Arabic]].<ref>[http://www.ascleiden.nl/content/acquisition-highlights/heinemann-african-writers-series "Heinemann African Writers Series"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150429153937/http://www.ascleiden.nl/content/acquisition-highlights/heinemann-african-writers-series |date=April 29, 2015 }} at [[African Studies Centre, Leiden]].</ref>
==History== Founded in 1962, the AWS created a forum for many post-independence African writers, and provided texts that African universities could use to address the colonial bias then prominent in the teaching of literature. The books were designed for classroom use, printed solely in paperback to make them affordable for African students. They were published by Heinemann Educational Books (HEB) in London and in various African cities.
The idea of the series came from Heinemann executive Alan Hill, who "recognised that the nascent post-colonial publishing industry was not supporting the growth of original African literature".<ref>Akin Ajayi, [https://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2010/feb/16/africa-writers-series-penguin-heinemann "Books Blog: Penguin's African Writers Series is stuck in the past"], ''The Guardian'', 17 February 2010.</ref><ref name="Kalliney2013">{{cite book|author=Peter J. Kalliney|title=Commonwealth of Letters: British Literary Culture and the Emergence of Postcolonial Aesthetics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dVq0oyc4JKwC&pg=PA179|year=2013|publisher=OUP USA|isbn=978-0-19-997797-0|pages=178–217|chapter=Metropolitan Publisher as Postcolonial Clearinghouse: The African Writers Series}}</ref> The first advisory editor to the series was the [[Nigerian]] [[Chinua Achebe]] – who became one of Africa's most famous writers. Achebe focused first on [[West Africa]]n writers, but soon the series branched out, publishing the works of Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o in [[East Africa]], and Nadine Gordimer in [[South Africa]]. Achebe left the editorship in 1972. James Currey, the editorial director at Heinemann Educational Books in charge of the African Writers Series from 1967 to 1984, has provided a book-length treatment of the series entitled ''Africa Writes Back''.<ref>{{Cite book |last= Currey |first= James |year= 2008 |title= Africa Writes Back: The African Writers Series and the Launch of African Literature |location= Oxford |publisher= [[James Currey]] |isbn= 978-1-847-01502-0 }}</ref><ref>Joseph L. Mbele, [http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/cls/summary/v046/46.2.mbele.html "Africa Writes Back: The African Writers Series & the Launch of African Literature (review)"], from ''Comparative Literature Studies'', Vol. 46, No. 2, 2009, pp. 425-428. Excerpted at Project Muse.</ref>
After a fairly successful beginning, the series faced difficulties that mirrored those that faced the continent. By the mid-1980s, Heinemann published only one or two new titles a year, and much of the back catalogue fell out of print. By the early 1990s, however, the series began to revive—having recently branched into new work, republishing originally locally released texts, and releasing translated works.
The AWS was relaunched by [[Pearson Education]] in 2011.<ref>[http://www.naijastories.com/2011/08/pearson-revives-african-writers-series-calls-for-submissions/ "Pearson revives African Writers Series, calls for submissions"], Naija Stories, 4 August 2011.</ref><ref>Nicholas Norbrook, [http://www.theafricareport.com/Books/publishing-africa-writers-series-celebrates-50-years.html "Publishing Africa Writers Series celebrates 50 years"], ''The Africa Report'', 29 February 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.pearsonschoolsandfecolleges.co.uk/international/Africa/Secondary/EnglishLiterature/African%20Writers%20Series/AfricanWritersSeries/AfricanWritersSeries.aspx "A celebrated selection of literature from Africa"], Pearson.</ref>

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Antonine Barada | image = [[File:Antonine Barada.jpg|Antoine Barada and wife, Elizabeth Robidoux; Mary Kihega, Lena Kihega.|250px]] | caption = Antoine Barada and wife, Elizabeth Robidoux; Mary Kihega, Lena Kihega | native_name = Mo shi-no pazhi | native_name_lang = {{lang-oma}} | birth_date = {{Birth date|1807|08|22}} | birth_place = [[St. Marys, Iowa]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1885|03|30|1807|08|22}} | death_place = [[Barada, Nebraska]] | nationality = [[Omaha people|Omaha]]-[[French people|French]] | other_names = Antoine Barada | occupation = Trader | known_for = Folk Hero, Legendary Strength }}
'''Antonine Barada''' (August 22, 1807 – March 30, 1885), alternatively spelled '''Antoine Barada''', was an American [[folk hero]] in the state of [[Nebraska]]; son of an [[Omaha people|Omaha]] mother, he was also called '''Mo shi-no pazhi''' in the tribal language.<ref name="Half-Breed Creek">Sandage, S.A. (2006) [http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/University_Library/amersem/sandage.pdf "Half-Breed Creek"]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Brown University. Retrieved 1/28/08.</ref> While Barada was an historic man, contemporary accounts of his prodigious strength helped establish him as a regional legend, in the mold of [[Paul Bunyan]] and [[Febold Feboldson]].<ref>Suttle, J.K. [http://ioway.nativeweb.org/history/barada_antoine.htm "Antoine Barada"], Baxoje, The Ioway Nation website. Retrieved 1/26/08.</ref> Barada's exploits have been counted as [[fakelore]] by historians.
== Early life == Antoine Barada was born in 1807 at [[St. Marys, Iowa]], which was once located across the Missouri River from [[Nemaha County, Nebraska]]. His parents were [[Michel Barada]], a French-American [[fur trapper]] and interpreter, and ''Ta-ing-the-hae,'' or "Laughing Buffalo", a full-blood [[Omaha (tribe)|Omaha]] and sister to the chief.<ref name="Half-Breed Creek" /><ref>Suttle, J.K., "Antoine Barada", ''Daily Tribune'', Hastings, Nebraska; Monday, September 8, 1975; reprinted at [http://ioway.nativeweb.org/history/barada_antoine.htm "Antoine Barada"], ''Baxoje,'' The Ioway Nation website. Retrieved 1/26/08.</ref> His namesake grandfather, [[Antoine Barada, Sr.]] (1739–1782), was born in [[Gascony, France]], and was one of the first settlers of [[St. Louis, Missouri]].
In 1813 Antoine was abducted by the [[Lakota people|Lakota]] while the family lived near [[Fort Lisa (Nebraska)]]. Six months later he was returned, after Michel Barada paid the ransom of two [[pony|ponies]]. His father immediately sent the boy to live with an aunt in St. Louis. At the age of nine, Antoine returned to the Plains with an Indian hunting party.
As a young man, Antoine Barada married Marcellite Vient, a French woman from St. Louis. In 1856 they returned to Nebraska to settle on the [[Nemaha Half-Breed Reservation]]; because of his half-Omaha ancestry, Barada was eligible for a land patent from the US government. He set up a trading post at the reservation, from which the town of [[Barada, Nebraska|Barada]] grew.<ref name="Half-Breed Creek" /> He and his wife settled {{convert|15|mi|km}} northeast of [[Falls City, Nebraska]].<ref>Edwards, L.C. (1917) "Antoine Barada", in ''[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.com/~ewilhelm/history.pdf History of Richardson County, Nebraska: Its people, industries and institutions.]'' Indianapolis: B.F. Bowen. p. 190-192.</ref>
== Myth == Barada's myth is widely known in Nebraska. In ''[[Love Song to the Plains]]'', the early 20th-century [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning writer [[Mari Sandoz]] stated, "'Toine Barada stories were told as far as the upper Yellowstone."<ref name="brown.edu">(2006) [http://www.brown.edu/Facilities/University_Library/amersem/sandage.pdf "Half-Breed Creek"]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Brown University. Retrieved 1/28/08.</ref><ref>Welsch, R. (1984) ''A Treasury of Nebraska Pioneer Folklore'', Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, p 171.</ref> In the 1930s, [[Louise Pound]] of the [[Federal Writer's Project]] of the [[Works Progress Administration]] collected dozens of stories about Barada, many of which are repeated today. One tale reported, "He was once matched to wrestle with [[Jean Palos]], a [[Greece|Greek]] wrestling champion... The mighty Palos was notorious for his rough treatment of an opponent. Antonine won the match by pinching his opponent with his toes while he slapped him into unconsciousness with one blow on his ear."<ref name="brown.edu" />
Barada was known as a huge man, commonly thought to be almost seven feet tall and widely regarded as a [[Giant (mythology)|giant]]. His strength was well known as well, and he was always asked to assist with [[barn raising]], as he would single-handedly hold heavy beams in place while they were fastened down. When local farmers needed assistance loading [[Domestic pig|hog]]s for [[Market (place)|market]], they would also call on Barada. Rather than use a [[loading chute]], Barada simply picked the hogs up and set them in the wagon. Every time townsfolk needed someone's strength, Barada took the call.<ref>Boye, A. (1993) ''The Complete Roadside Guide to Nebraska.'' University of Nebraska Press. p 2.</ref>
In 1832 Barada was in St. Louis when he was challenged to prove his strength. He lifted a stone weighing 1,700 pounds, after which point the date of the feat and the weight were inscribed on the stone for future generations. The stone is purported to still stand there. Barada was also widely regarded for his [[marksmanship]]. Lore recorded his ability to shoot [[prairie chicken]]s on the fly from horseback, as well as the ability to shoot two [[quail]] from every covey. He was known as a fair hunter, one who never shot a bird on the ground.
One tale of Barada recounted that while working with a lazy railroad crew in Nebraska, Barada became upset. He grabbed the drop hammer and threw it across the [[Missouri River]], at which point the earth where the hammer fell buckled. The hammer fall created Nebraska's Missouri River breaks. Barada was still angry and slammed his fist down on a [[Deep foundation|pile]]. It was driven so far into the soil that it pierced a [[water table]]. Legend says that all of Nebraska would have flooded from this [[bung hole]] if Antoine Barada hadn't plugged it by sitting over it.<ref>[http://www.folkstreams.net/context,270 "Transcription: Working script by filmmaker Maria Brooks"], FolkStreams. Retrieved 1/28/08.</ref> Antonine was also purportedly involved in the Underground Railroad. Known as the "Lifeguard of the Missouri", Barada supposedly saved many slaves from drowning by personally carrying them across the Missouri River from the state of [[Missouri]] into Nebraska.<ref name="Half-Breed Creek" />
== Half-Breed Tract == Barada received a patent on {{convert|320|acre|km2}} of land in 1856<ref name="Barada">[http://casde.unl.edu/history/counties/richardson/barada/ "Barada"], University of Nebraska. Retrieved 1/28/08.</ref> on the [[Nemaha Half-Breed Reservation]]. The town of [[Barada, Nebraska|Barada]] was established in that tract soon after Barada's claim. Barada ran a fur-trading post there for at least 20 years, during which time the town grew around him.<ref name="Barada" />
==Death== Barada died in 1885 and is buried alongside his wife in the Catholic cemetery just east of Barada, the village that bears his name.
In 1951 several of Barada's descendants were members of a [[lawsuit]] brought against the [[Government of the United States]] for recognition of their descent from a full tribal member of the Omaha nation, and their entitlement to compensation related to land allotments and financial benefits received by tribal members. According to the suit, in the 1870s Barada applied to the tribe for membership based on his maternal ancestry. He was rejected due to discriminatory practices by tribal elders and [[Indian Bureau|Indian agents]]. Unlike many Native American tribes, the Omaha have a [[patrilineal]] system of descent, so may have rejected Barada because of his French-American father.<ref name="TrueLogan"/> They considered children with European/white fathers to be "white" and did not accept them into the tribe unless they were officially adopted.<ref name="TrueLogan">[http://www.usgennet.org/usa/ne/topic/resources/OLLibrary/collections/vol19/v19p064.htm Melvin Randolph Gilmore, "The True Logan Fontenelle"], ''Publications of the Nebraska State Historical Society,'' Vol. 19, edited by Albert Watkins, Nebraska State Historical Society, 1919, pp. 64-65, at GenNet, accessed 25 August 2011</ref>
In the 1951 case, the Indian Claims Commission acknowledged there might have been discrimination by the tribe against certain mixed-blood descendants such as Barada; however, the court dismissed the case on the grounds that the Indian Claims Commission did not have jurisdiction over a group claim of individual members; rather, its responsibilities were to adjudicate claims of tribes against the government.<ref>[http://digital.library.okstate.edu/icc/v01/iccv01p683.pdf "Josephine Mitchell, et al., on relation to ''Omaha tribe of Indians of Nebraska vs. United States Government''."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081119153230/http://digital.library.okstate.edu/icc/v01/iccv01p683.pdf |date=November 19, 2008 }} Oklahoma State University. Retrieved 1/28/08.</ref> The federal government has continued to defer to the federally recognized tribes' sovereignty to determine their own rules for membership and eligibility for voting and benefits.
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== * Sandage, S.A. (2008) ''Half-Breed Creek: A Tall Tale of Race on the Frontier, 1804–1941.'' [http://www.thetartan.org/2007/1/22/news/sandage Announcement]
{{American tall tales}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Barada, Antonine}} [[Category:1807 births]] [[Category:1887 deaths]] [[Category:American folklore]] [[Category:People from Warren County, Iowa]] [[Category:People from Richardson County, Nebraska]] [[Category:Giants]] [[Category:Tall tales]] [[Category:Native American history of Nebraska]] [[Category:American fur traders]] [[Category:American Métis people]] [[Category:People of the American Old West]] [[Category:Nebraska people of French descent]] [[Category:Nebraska folklore]]

'''Auguste Toussaint''' (1911<ref>{{fr icon}} In ''L'Ile Maurice et sa civilisation'' de Noël d'Unienville, p. 112, 1949.</ref> – 1987)<ref>[http://www.idref.fr/027167461 ''Toussaint, Auguste (8 September 1911 - 18 January 1987)''.] IDREF-Autorités Sudoc.</ref> was the Archivist in Chief of [[Mauritius]]<ref>{{fr icon}} [http://daf.archivesdefrance.culture.gouv.fr/sdx-222-daf-bora-ap/ap/pdf.xsp?id=DAFANCAOM00AP_000000151&f=d.pdf archives de France] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720232100/http://daf.archivesdefrance.culture.gouv.fr/sdx-222-daf-bora-ap/ap/pdf.xsp?id=DAFANCAOM00AP_000000151&f=d.pdf |date=July 20, 2011 }}</ref> and an historian of his island, [[Mascarene Islands]] and [[Indian Ocean]].
==Bibliography== In French * 1992 - ''L'océan Indien au XVIIIe'', éd. [[Groupe Flammarion|Flammarion]], * 1980 - ''Histoire de l'océan Indien'', collection ''[[Que sais-je?]]'', éd. [[PUF]] * 1979 - ''Les Frères Surcouf'', éd. Flammarion, Paris * 1978 - ''Histoire des corsaires'', collection ''Que sais-je ?'', éd. PUF * 1974 - ''L'Océan Indien au XVIIIe'', éd. Flammarion, Paris. * 1971 - ''Histoire de l'île Maurice'', éd. PUF * 1967 - ''La Route des îles : Contribution à l'histoire maritime des Mascareignes'', éd. S.E.V.P.E.N. * 1966 - ''Une Cité tropicale, Port-Louis de l'Ile Maurice'', éd. PUF Vendôme
In English * 1954 - ''Bibliography of Mauritius (1502-1954)'' avec H. Adolphe, Esclapon Limited, Port Louis
==References== <references/>

revision.comment: /* CiteSeer<sup>x</sup> */Fixing [[Wikipedia:Disambiguation pages with links|links to disambiguation pages]], replaced: [[open source]] → [[Open-source software|open source]]
revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:CiteSeer<sup>X</sup>}}<!-- apparently the correct title is either CiteSeer<sup>x</sup> or CiteSeerX but DISPLAYTITLE only allows changing an initial letter to lower case --> {{more citations needed|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox website | name = CiteSeer<sup>x</sup> | url = {{Official URL}} | commercial = | type = [[Bibliographic database]] | language = | registration = Optional | content_license = [[Creative Commons license|Creative Commons BY-NC-SA license]]<ref name=CC-license /> | owner = [[Pennsylvania State University]] College of Information Sciences and Technology | launch date = {{start date and age|2007}} | current status = Active | revenue = }} '''CiteSeer<sup>x</sup>''' (originally called '''CiteSeer''') is a public [[Search engine (computing)|search engine]] and [[digital library]] for scientific and academic papers, primarily in the fields of [[computer science|computer]] and [[information science]]. CiteSeer holds a United States patent # 6289342, titled "''Autonomous citation indexing and literature browsing using citation context''," granted on September 11, 2001. Stephen R. Lawrence, C. Lee Giles, Kurt D. Bollacker are the inventors of this patent assigned to NEC Laboratories America, Inc. This patent was filed on May 20, 1998, which has its roots (Priority) to January 5, 1998. A continuation patent was also granted to the same inventors and also assigned to NEC Labs on this invention i.e. US Patent # 6738780 granted on May 18, 2004 and was filed on May 16, 2001. CiteSeer is considered as a predecessor of academic search tools such as [[Google Scholar]] and [[Microsoft Academic Search]].{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} CiteSeer-like engines and archives usually only harvest documents from publicly available websites and do not crawl publisher websites. For this reason, authors whose documents are freely available are more likely to be represented in the index.
CiteSeer's goal is to improve the dissemination and access of academic and scientific literature. As a non-profit service that can be freely used by anyone, it has been considered as part of the [[Open access (publishing)|open access]] movement that is attempting to change [[academic publishing|academic and scientific publishing]] to allow greater access to scientific literature. CiteSeer freely provided [[Open Archives Initiative]] [[metadata]] of all indexed documents and links indexed documents when possible to other sources of metadata such as [[DBLP]] and the [[ACM Portal]]. To promote [[open data]], '''CiteSeer<sup>x</sup>''' shares its data for non-commercial purposes under a Creative Commons license.<ref name=CC-license>{{Cite web|url = http://csxstatic.ist.psu.edu/about/data|title = CiteSeerX Data Policy|date = |accessdate = 2015-11-10|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
The name can be construed to have at least two explanations. As a pun, a 'sightseer' is a tourist who looks at the sights, so a 'cite seer' would be a researcher who looks at cited papers. Another is a 'seer' is a prophet and a 'cite seer' is a prophet of citations. CiteSeer changed its name to ResearchIndex at one point and then changed it back.
== History ==
=== CiteSeer and CiteSeer.IST === CiteSeer was created by researchers [[Lee Giles]], [[Kurt Bollacker]] and [[Steve Lawrence (computer scientist)|Steve Lawrence]] in 1997 while they were at the [[NEC Research Institute]] (now [[NEC Laboratories America|NEC Labs]]), [[Princeton, New Jersey]], USA. CiteSeer's goal was to actively crawl and harvest academic and scientific documents on the web and use autonomous [[citation index]]ing to permit querying by citation or by document, ranking them by [[citation impact]]. At one point, it was called ResearchIndex.
CiteSeer became public in 1998 and had many new features unavailable in academic search engines at that time. These included: * Autonomous Citation Indexing automatically created a citation index that can be used for literature search and evaluation. * Citation statistics and related documents were computed for all articles cited in the database, not just the indexed articles. * Reference linking allowing browsing of the database using citation links. * Citation context showed the context of citations to a given paper, allowing a researcher to quickly and easily see what other researchers have to say about an article of interest. * Related documents were shown using citation and word based measures and an active and continuously updated bibliography is shown for each document.
After NEC, in 2004 it was hosted as CiteSeer.IST on the [[World Wide Web]] at the College of Information Sciences and Technology, The [[Pennsylvania State University]], and had over 700,000 documents. For enhanced access, performance and research, similar versions of CiteSeer were supported at universities such as the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], [[University of Zürich]] and the [[National University of Singapore]]. However, these versions of CiteSeer proved difficult to maintain and are no longer available. Because CiteSeer only indexes freely available papers on the web and does not have access to publisher metadata, it returns fewer citation counts than sites, such as [[Google Scholar]], that have publisher metadata. <!-- for historical reference: Versions of CiteSeer have been or are available at the following links: * [http://citeseer.ittc.ku.edu Univ. of Kansas] * [http://citeseer.csail.mit.edu MIT] * [http://sherry.ifi.unizh.ch Univ. of Zürich] * [http://citeseer.comp.nus.edu.sg/cs National Univ. of Singapore]
-->
CiteSeer had not been comprehensively updated since 2005 due to limitations in its architecture design. It had a representative sampling of research documents in computer and information science but was limited in coverage because it was limited to papers that are publicly available, usually at an author's homepage, or those submitted by an author. To overcome some of these limitations, a modular and open source architecture for CiteSeer was designed - CiteSeer<sup>x</sup>.
=== CiteSeer<sup>x</sup> === '''CiteSeer<sup>x</sup>''' replaced CiteSeer and all queries to CiteSeer were redirected. CiteSeer<sup>x</sup><ref name="about-page">{{Cite web |title=About CiteSeerX |accessdate=2010-05-07 |url=http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/about/site}}</ref> is a public [[search engine]] and [[digital library]] and [[Disciplinary repository|repository]] for scientific and academic papers primarily with a focus on [[computer science|computer]] and [[information science]].<ref name="about-page"/> However, recently CiteSeer<sup>x</sup> has been expanding into other scholarly domains such as economics, physics and others. Released in 2008, it was loosely based on the previous CiteSeer search engine and digital library and is built with a new [[Open-source software|open source]] infrastructure, SeerSuite, and new algorithms and their implementations. It was developed by researchers Dr. Isaac Councill and Dr. C. [[Lee Giles]] at [[Penn State College of Information Sciences and Technology|the College of Information Sciences and Technology]], [[Pennsylvania State University]]. It continues to support the goals outlined by CiteSeer to actively crawl and harvest academic and scientific documents on the public web and to use a citation inquery by citations and ranking of documents by the impact of citations. Currently, Lee Giles, Prasenjit Mitra, Susan Gauch, Min-Yen Kan, Pradeep Teregowda, Juan Pablo Fernández Ramírez, Pucktada Treeratpituk, Jian Wu, Douglas Jordan, Steve Carman, Jack Carroll, Jim Jansen, and Shuyi Zheng are or have been actively involved in its development. Recently, a table search feature was introduced.<ref>{{Cite web |title=The CiteSeerX Team |url=http://csxstatic.ist.psu.edu/about/team |publisher=Pennsylvania State University |df=mdy |accessdate=2018-05-01}}</ref> It has been funded by the [[National Science Foundation]], [[NASA]], and [[Microsoft Research]].
CiteSeer<sup>x</sup> continues to be rated as one of the world's top repositories and was rated number 1 in July 2010.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Ranking Web of World Repositories: Top 800 Repositories |publisher=Cybermetrics Lab |date=July 2010 |url=http://repositories.webometrics.info/top800_rep.asp |accessdate=2010-07-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100724004342/http://repositories.webometrics.info/top800_rep.asp |archivedate=2010-07-24 |df=mdy}}</ref> It currently has over 6 million documents with nearly 6 million unique authors and 120 million citations.
CiteSeer<sup>x</sup> also shares its software, data, databases and metadata with other researchers, currently by [[Amazon S3]] and by [[rsync]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=About CiteSeerX Data |publisher=Pennsylvania State University |accessdate=2012-01-25 |url=http://csxstatic.ist.psu.edu/about/data}}</ref> Its new modular open source architecture and software (available previously on [[SourceForge]] but now on [[GitHub]]) is built on [[Apache Solr]] and other [[Apache Software Foundation|Apache]] and open source tools which allows it to be a testbed for new algorithms in document harvesting, ranking, indexing, and information extraction.
== Current features ==
=== Automated information extraction === CiteSeer<sup>x</sup> uses automated information extraction tools, usually built on machine learning methods such ParsCit, to extract scholarly document metadata such as title, authors, abstract, citations, etc. As such, there are sometime errors in authors and titles. Other academic search engines have similar errors.
=== Focused crawling === CiteSeer<sup>x</sup> crawls publicly available scholarly documents primarily from author webpages and other open resources, and does not have access to publisher metadata. As such citation counts in CiteSeer<sup>x</sup> are usually less than those in Google Scholar and Microsoft Academic Search who have access to publisher metadata.
=== Usage === CiteSeer<sup>x</sup> has nearly 1 million users worldwide based on unique IP addresses and has millions of hits daily. Annual downloads of document PDFs was nearly 200 million for 2015.
=== Data === CiteSeer<sup>x</sup> data is regularly shared under a [[Creative Commons license|Creative Commons BY-NC-SA license]] with researchers worldwide and has been and is used in many experiments and competitions.
== Other SeerSuite-based search engines == The CiteSeer model had been extended to cover academic documents in business with [[SmealSearch]] and in e-business with [[eBizSearch]]. However, these were not maintained by their sponsors. An older version of both of these could be once found at [[BizSeer.IST]] but is no longer in service.
Other Seer-like search and repository systems have been built for chemistry, [[ChemXSeer|Chem<sub>X</sub>Seer]] and for archaeology, ArchSeer. Another had been built for robots.txt file search, [[BotSeer]]. All of these are built on the open source tool [[SeerSuite]], which uses the open source indexer [[Lucene]].
== See also == {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[arXiv]] * [[Google Scholar]] * [[Microsoft Academic]] * [[Semantic Scholar]] * [[Collection of Computer Science Bibliographies]] * [[DBLP]] (Digital Bibliography & Library Project) * [[List of academic databases and search engines]] * [[Arnetminer]] * [[Disciplinary repository]] * [[Research Papers in Economics]] (RePEc) {{div col end}}
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
== Further reading == * {{cite journal|title=CiteSeer: an automatic citation indexing system|year=1998|citeseerx=10.1.1.30.6847|doi=10.1145/276675.276685|last1=Giles|first1=C. Lee|last2=Bollacker|first2=Kurt D.|last3=Lawrence|first3=Steve|isbn=0-89791-965-3 |journal=Proceedings of the third ACM conference on Digital libraries |pages= 89–98 }}
== External links == {{Wikidata property|1=P3784}} * {{official website|name=Official website of CiteSeer<sup>x</sup>}} * {{GitHub|SeerLabs/CiteSeerX}} * {{SourceForge|citeseerx|SeerSuite}} (historic)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Citeseer}} [[Category:Bibliographic databases in computer science]] [[Category:Eprint archives]] [[Category:Internet search engines]] [[Category:Library 2.0]] [[Category:Online databases]] [[Category:Open-access archives]] [[Category:Pennsylvania State University]] [[Category:Scholarly search services]]

There are several companies that manufacture models of graphing calculators. [[Texas Instruments]] is a major manufacturer. The '''''[[Computerworld]]'' Smithsonian Award''' is given out annually to individuals who have used technology to produce beneficial changes for society. Nominees are proposed by a group of 100 CEOs of information technology companies. The award has been given since 1989.<ref>[http://siris-archives.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?uri=full=3100001~!140524!0 The Computer World Smithsonian Awards, 1989–2001], [[Smithsonian Institution]].</ref>
==Winners== * 1989 - Inaugural winners, all listed: Bell & Howell's Image Plus Search System; Orangeburg School District 5, Orangeburg, South Carolina; Passaic River Basin Early Flood Warning System, Sierra-Micro Inc.; FIX and FAST, Fidelity Investments; The Missing Children Project, University of Illinois; BI Home Escort System; University of Iowa's National Advanced Driving Simulator; Live Aid, Uplinger Enterprise; The Eyegaze Computer, LC Technologies; American Airlines SABRE Reservation Service; The Innovis DesignCenter. * 1992 — A Search for New Heroes * 1993 — Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.psc.edu/publicinfo/news/1993/cwsmithson.html|title=Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center Wins Computerworld Smithsonian Award for Science}}</ref> a joint project of Carnegie Mellon University and the University of Pittsburgh together with Westinghouse Electric Corporation, established in 1986 by a grant from the National Science Foundation with support from the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. Its purpose is to develop and make available state-of-the-art high-performance computing for scientific researchers nationwide. * 1994 — LOS ALAMOS NATIONAL LABORATORY Parallel Ocean Program (POP)<ref name=chwhonors>{{cite web|url=http://www.cwhonors.org/search/caa_5.asp|title=ComputerWorld Honors Website}}</ref> * 1995 — NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE, INC. Integrated Technology Plan<ref name=chwhonors/> * 1996 — Carnegie Mellon FastLab, a multi-university real time financial trading simulator, for visionary use of information technology in the field of education and academia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://public.tepper.cmu.edu/facultydirectory/FacultyDirectoryProfile.aspx?id=104|title=Carnegie Mellon University, Bio of Professor John O'Brien}}</ref> * 1997 — METROPOLITAN TORONTO POLICE, the "Metropolis" program, for technology innovations in policing, including the Computer Aided Dispatch (CAD) system, the automated 911 Emergency Response System, the Computer-Aided Scheduling of Courts system, the Repository of Integrated Computer Images (mugshot) system, the Criminals Information Processing System, the Computer Assisted Reconstruction Enhancement System, and many others<ref>Metro Toronto Police Computerworld Smithsonian Case Study {{cite web |url=http://www.cwhonors.org/Search/his_4a_detail.asp?id=2718 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-07-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130725142729/http://www.cwhonors.org/Search/his_4a_detail.asp?id=2718 |archivedate=2013-07-25 |df= }}</ref> * 1998 — UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, BERKELEY'S SEARCH FOR EXTRATERRESTRIAL INTELLIGENCE (SETI) PROGRAM<ref name="chwhonors" /> * 1998 - William E. Kelvie, Fannie Mae, the first internet originated mortgage * 1999 — [[Virtual Operating Room]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cwhonors.org/Search/his_4a_detail.asp?id=962 |title=Virtual Operating Room (Virtual-OR) |work=Computerworld Honors |accessdate=2012-05-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229195942/http://www.cwhonors.org/Search/his_4a_detail.asp?id=962 |archivedate=2012-02-29 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * 2000 — [[EBay]], [[Montgomery County Public Schools (Maryland)|Montgomery County Public Schools]], Department of Primary Industry and Fisheries, Proton World, Independent Electoral Commission of South Africa, Danfoss Drives, [[National Marrow Donor Program]], [[RealNetworks]], Hawkes Ocean Technology, [[Delta Air Lines]], [[Blackboard Inc.]].,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/45660/Technology_innovators_presented_with_Smithsonian_awards_ |title=Technology innovators presented with Smithsonian awards |date=June 8, 2000 |author=Linda Rosencrance |archivedate=2012-05-07 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67TdWaTV3?url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/45660/Technology_innovators_presented_with_Smithsonian_awards_ |publisher=[[Computerworld]] |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> ROGER MAHABIR, CIO, ROYAL BANK OF CANADA DOMINION SECURITIES for advanced internet security techniques support the buying and selling of foreign currencies over the internet, supporting billions of dollars of business in the first year of operation.<ref>[http://www.cwhonors.org/Search/his_4a_detail.asp?id=3807 http://www.cwhonors.org/Search/his_4a_detail.asp?id=3807 Royal Bank of Canada Dominion Securities, Computerworld Smithsonian Case Study] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130725142731/http://www.cwhonors.org/Search/his_4a_detail.asp?id=3807 |date=2013-07-25 }}</ref>

{{Use British English|date=February 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox court case | name = Dec. No. 5946/212/2015 | court = Curtea de Apel Constanța<ref name="script"/> | image = Alexandra Stan v. Marcel Prodan.PNG | imagesize = 200px | caption = [[Alexandra Stan]] (''right'') was involved in the court case along with Marcel Prodan (''left''). | date decided = 21 December 2016<ref name="script"/> | full name = 5946/212/2015<ref name="script"/> | citations = | judges = | prior actions = | subsequent actions = | opinions = | transcripts = | Keywords = }}
'''''Dec. No. 5946/212/2015''''' refers to a Curtea de Apel Constanța (Constanța Court of Appeal) lawsuit in which Romanian singer [[Alexandra Stan]] accused her [[impresario]] Marcel Prodan of blackmail, battery, deception and tax evasion. In June 2013, Stan and Prodan were travelling in a car on the [[A2 motorway (Romania)|Autostrada Soarelui]] (Sun Motorway) between [[Constanța]] and [[Valu lui Traian]]. They were stopped by police officers who found them fighting and Stan was taken to hospital. The singer later appeared on national television with evidence of assault visible on her face, generating media attention in Romania. Observers were generally on Stan's side.
According to the singer, the incident occurred after she asked Prodan for her earnings; he reacted violently and asaulted her. Prodan said he had acted in self-defence after Stan hit him in his car and threatened to commit suicide. After several hearings with magistrates, Prodan received a seven-month suspended sentence for "the crime of battery or other violence" and was assessed damages. The court ruled Stan's other accusations were groundless and she was fined court costs, although Prodan's fines were later increased. This decision was handed down by the court on 21 December 2016.
=={{anchor|Background and incident}}Background== [[File:A2-A4-02.jpg|thumb|left|The Autostrada Soarelui, where a car containing Stan and Prodan was stopped by police and the singer taken to hospital]]
In 2009, [[Alexandra Stan]] was discovered at a karaoke bar by Romanian producers and songwriters Marcel Prodan and Andrei Nemirschi, who offered her a record deal with their label Maan Records. That year she recorded a promotional single, "Show Me The Way".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.urban.ro/muzica/o-noua-voce-alexandra-stan/|title=O noua voce: Alexandra Stan|publisher=Urban.ro|language=Romanian|accessdate=16 October 2015|date=25 November 2009|trans-title=A new singer: Alexandra Stan|archivedate=17 October 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017144619/http://www.urban.ro/muzica/o-noua-voce-alexandra-stan/}}</ref> In 2011, Stan's single "[[Mr. Saxobeat]]" topped the [[Romanian Top 100]] chart for eight consecutive weeks.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/alexandra-stan-mn0002651146/biography|title=AllMusic: Alexandra Stan | publisher=[[AllMusic]] | accessdate=1 November 2015}}</ref> The song was also commercially successful abroad, topping record charts in Austria, Denmark, Germany, Hungary, Israel, Italy, Slovakia, Switzerland and Turkey.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.austriancharts.at/showitem.asp?interpret=Alexandra+Stan&titel=Mr.+Saxobeat&cat=s|title=Austriancharts.at – Alexandra Stan – Mr. Saxobeat | publisher=[[Ö3 Austria Top 40]] | language=German|accessdate=13 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://zene.slagerlistak.hu/radios-top-40-jatszasi-lista/2011/24|title=Archívum – Slágerlisták – MAHASZ | publisher=[[MAHASZ|Rádiós Top 40 játszási lista]]. Magyar Hanglemezkiadók Szövetsége|accessdate=13 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ifpicr.cz/hitparadask/index.php?hitp=R |title=SNS IFPI |publisher=Hitparáda – Radio Top 100 Oficiálna. IFPI Czech Republic |language=Slovak |accessdate=13 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070110021817/http://www.ifpicr.cz/hitparadask/index.php?hitp=R |archivedate=10 January 2007 |df= }} ''Note: insert 201114 into search.''</ref> It was the first Romanian song to top the [[German Singles Chart]] since [[O-Zone]]'s "[[Dragostea Din Tei]]" in 2004.<ref name="fullbio">{{cite web | url=http://stirileprotv.ro/show-buzz/entertainment/alexandra-stan-neaga-implicarea-intr-un-accident-rutier-ce-a-patit-artista-in-realitate.html|title=Alexandra Stan, despre cel care a desfigurat-o: "Am fost indragostita de el. El ma numea sclava lui"| publisher=''[[Pro TV|Știrile Pro TV]]'' | language=Romanian|trans-title=Alexandra Stan on the guy that disfigured her: "I was in love with him. He named me his slave."|accessdate=13 February 2016|archivedate=29 December 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151229163141/http://stirileprotv.ro/show-buzz/entertainment/alexandra-stan-neaga-implicarea-intr-un-accident-rutier-ce-a-patit-artista-in-realitate.html}}</ref>
According to spokesmen for the Poliţia Judeţeană Constanţa (Constanţa Country Police Department), on 16 June 2013,<ref name="ny daily">{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/romanian-singer-alexandra-stan-claims-manager-boyfriend-beat-article-1.1375889|author=[[The Associated Press]]|publisher=''[[New York Daily News]]''|title=Romanian singer Alexandra Stan claims manager-boyfriend beat her up after fight over money|date=18 June 2013|accessdate=1 January 2017}}</ref> Stan was picked up from the Autostrada Soarelui (Sun Motorway), which connects the cities of [[Constanța]] and [[Valu lui Traian]], at about 19:00 by Poliția Rutieră (traffic police), who saw a man and a woman fighting in a car on the shoulder of the motorway. The parties were identified as Stan and Prodan; Stan had visible evidence of physical assault (facial bruises), prompting the police to suggest she be taken to hospital and possibly file a complaint against her assailant. Stan was taken to Spitalul Clinic Judeţean de Urgenţă Constanţa (Constanța County Emergency Hospital), where she was treated and released.<ref name="mediafax">{{cite news|url=http://www.mediafax.ro/life-inedit/alexandra-stan-desfigurata-dupa-ce-ar-fi-fost-batuta-de-manager-foto-10977576|title=Alexandra Stan, desfigurată după ce ar fi fost bătută de manager|trans-title=Alexandra Stan, disfigured after her alleged fight with her manager|date=17 June 2013|publisher=Mediafax|author=Legănel, Cătălin|accessdate=1 January 2017|language=Romanian}}</ref>
=={{anchor|Accusations and hearings}}Allegations and hearings== After Stan was taken to another hospital in [[Medgidia]], she accused Prodan of physical abuse,<ref name="stiri"/> and later filed complaints of blackmail, battery, deception and tax evasion.<ref name="stiri"/><ref name="ziarulring">{{cite news|url=http://www.ziarulring.ro/-alexandra-stan-executare-silita|title=Alexandra Stan, la un pas de executare silită. Cum a ajuns în această situaţie|trans-title=Alexandra Stan, on the brink of foreclosure. How did she get in this situation?|language=Romanian|accessdate=16 February 2017|publisher=''Ziarul Ring''|date=16 February 2017}}</ref> Stan insisted that a message that she would cancel concerts because of a traffic accident was posted by Prodan on her social media and was untrue.<ref name="ny daily"/> Prodan did not immediately respond to the accusations and could not be reached by email or telephone.<ref name="ny daily"/> According to Stan, Prodan beat her to intimidate her about demanding money, a reported €40,000 earned from her concerts.<ref name="stiri"/><ref name="romania tv">{{cite news|url=http://www.romaniatv.net/verdict-final-alexandra-stan-l-a-agresat-pe-impresarul-marcel-prodan_182710.html|publisher=Romania TV|language=Romanian|trans-title=Bizarre verdict: Alexandra Stan assaulted Marcel Prodan, who was in "self defense"|title=Verdict bizar: Alexandra Stan l-a agresat pe Marcel Prodan, care era "în legitimă apărare"|accessdate=1 January 2017|date=10 November 2014|author=Costache, Alina}}</ref> At the hospital, Stan consulted a [[physiologist]], an [[ophthalmologist]] and a [[neurologist]].<ref name="stiri">{{cite news|url=http://stirileprotv.ro/stiri/actualitate/alexandra-stan-il-acuza-pe-marcel-prodan-de-santaj-in-plangerea-depusa-la-parchetul-din-constanta.html|title=Alexandra Stan a depus o plangere pentru santaj: "Nu dau inapoi". Prodan risca 6 ani de inchisoare|trans-title=Alexandra Stan filled a complaint for blackmail: "I won't go back". Prodan risks 6 years in jail|language=Romanian|accessdate=1 January 2017|publisher=''[[Pro TV|Știrile Pro TV]]''|date=18 June 2013}}</ref> She also appeared on national television, attracting media coverage in Romania.<ref name="ny daily"/>
In November 2014, judges from Constanța decided not to prosecute Prodan for Stan's complaint due to a lack of physical evidence;<ref name="romania tv"/> however, in June 2015 a preliminary hearing with magistrates was held. Prodan testified that he and Stan had "more than a professional relationship", which he planned to end. According to him, the incident began when he told Stan in his recording studio that she had sung poorly. Prodan alleged that Stan did not want to leave and he stated that he pushed her towards the exit. Prodan also stated that Stan slipped on a wet floor while trying to hit him. When describing the events in his car, Prodan said Stan began kicking him; he defended himself, slapping her when she jerked the steering wheel to the right. Prodan testified that Stan cried, said she wanted to commit suicide and opened the door to jump out of the car; he grabbed her hand and stopped. Stan, weeping during the hearing, said Prodan threw her into his car and struck her multiple times during the trip; in shock, she jerked the wheel to get out of the car. She denied their relationship extended beyond business.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.radiofxnet.ro/prima-intalnire-fata-judecatorilor-intre-alexandra-stan-si-marcel-prodan-fostul-manager-o-acuza-ca-vrut-sa-se-sinucida/# |title=Prima intalnire in fata judecatorilor intre Alexandra Stan si Marcel Prodan |trans-title=First face-to-face meeting of Alexandra Stan and Marcel Prodan |language=Romanian |publisher=Radio FX |accessdate=24 March 2016 |date=4 June 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406140637/http://www.radiofxnet.ro/prima-intalnire-fata-judecatorilor-intre-alexandra-stan-si-marcel-prodan-fostul-manager-o-acuza-ca-vrut-sa-se-sinucida/%23 |archivedate=6 April 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
In another hearing in late December 2015, Stan attended with her new boyfriend; during that hearing, the singer demanded more than €1 million in damages from Prodan. Prodan's ex-wife and Nicolae Nemirschi, the father of Prodan's songwriting and producing collaborator, Andrei Nemirschi, were also present, and they testified that the singer had an affair with Prodan, which Stan denied. Prodan's ex-wife said that their marriage ended after she placed a recording device in Prodan's car which provided evidence of his romantic relationship with Stan.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://stirileprotv.ro/stiri/actualitate/alexandra-stan-ii-cere-daune-de-un-milion-de-euro-fostului-manager-marcel-prodan-ce-a-declarat-cantareata-in-fata-instantei.html|title=Alexandra Stan ii cere daune de un milion de euro fostului manager, Marcel Prodan|trans-title=Alexandra Stan demands damage exceeding one million euros from past-manager Marcel Prodan|publisher=''[[Pro TV|Știrile Pro TV]]''|accessdate=1 January 2017|date=3 December 2015|language=Romanian}}</ref> On 19 February 2016, Prodan received a seven-month [[suspended sentence]] for "the crime of battery or other violence" and was ordered to pay Stan €193 for medical care and €10,000 in damages.<ref name="click2">{{cite news|url=http://www.click.ro/vedete/romanesti/impresarul-alexandrei-stan-7-luni-de-inchisoare-cu-suspendare|title= Impresarul Alexandrei Stan, 7 luni de închisoare cu suspendare|trans-title=Alexandra Stan's manager sentenced to 7 months of jail with suspension|language=Romanian|publisher=''Click''|accessdate=24 March 2016|date=19 February 2016|author=Ștefan, Carmen}}</ref> The court ruled that there was insufficient evidence to support the other accusations made by the singer, and it was reported in late November 2016 that Stan was assessed €500 in court costs.<ref name="loss">{{cite news|url=http://www.cotidianul.ro/alexandra-stan-a-pierdut-procesul-cu-fostul-impresar-291833/|language=Romanian|publisher=''[[Cotidianul]]''|title=Alexandra Stan a pierdut procesul cu fostul impresar|trans-title=Alexandra Stan lost the process with her former manager|date=25 November 2016|accessdate=11 December 2016}}</ref> On appeal, her damage award from Prodan<ref name="court">{{cite news|url=http://www.romania-insider.com/romanian-singer-alexandra-stans-manager-gets-7-month-probation-for-beating-her/|publisher=Romania-Insider|accessdate=27 November 2016|title=Romanian singer Alexandra Stan’s manager gets 7-month probation for beating her}}</ref> was increased to €25,000.<ref name="script">{{cite news|url=http://portal.just.ro/36/SitePages/Dosar.aspx?id_dosar=21200000000314430&id_inst=36|publisher=Curtea de Apel Constanța|language=Romanian|title=Informații dosar – 5946/212/2015|accessdate=21 January 2017}}</ref> That decision was finalised by the court on 21 December 2016.<ref name="script"/>
==Related legal proceedings and aftermath== After Stan's recovery, Prodan sued her for using his songs in her live performances,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.libertatea.ro/monden/vedete-de-la-noi/probleme-pentru-alexandra-stan-data-in-judecata-de-marcel-prodan-977548|title= Probleme pentru Alexandra Stan! Data in judecata de Marcel Prodan!|date=17 January 2014|publisher=[[Libertatea]]|accessdate=22 March 2016|language=Romanian|trans-title=Problems for Alexandra Stan! She was sued by Marcel Prodan!}}</ref> a copyright battle she eventually won in June 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cancan.ro/actualitate/a-castigat-procesul-cu-marcel-prodan-insa-alexandra-stan-nu-a-scapat-de-probleme-nemirschi-ii-interzice-sa-i-foloseasca-pozele.html|title= A castigat procesul cu Marcel Prodan, insa Alexandra Stan nu a scapat de probleme! Ce interdictie i-a pus celalalt fost manager|trans-title=She won the process with Marcel Prodan, but Alexandra Stan didn't get rid of problems! See what an interdiction her other manager set her|language=Romanian|date=26 June 2014|publisher=''Cancan''|accessdate=22 September 2015}}</ref> In February 2016, representatives of the law firm that represented Stan during her court process with Prodan filed suit against her alleging she failed to pay some fees. The judges dismissed the suit but the law firm filed an appeal of the decision.<ref name="ziarulring"/>
Romanian commentator Mircea Toma said, "The [Romanian] media treat this subject in a derisory way. A woman who is beaten is subject of irony, something sensationalist and the violence itself is not condemned. [The Romanians] have an archaic, patriarchal mentality, and it would be good for her to go all the way to get justice and a good opportunity for society to debate domestic violence."<ref name="ny daily"/> Stan received support from her fans and death threats against Prodan were posted on her social media accounts.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.romaniatv.net/marcel-prodan-managerul-bataus-al-alexandrei-stan-amenintat-cu-moartea_84963.html|title=Marcel Prodan, managerul bătăuş al Alexandrei Stan, amenintat cu moartea|trans-title=Marcel Prodan, Stan's manager, threaten with death|language=Romanian|publisher=Romania TV|author=Costache, Alina|date=18 June 2013|accessdate=1 January 2017}}</ref> Prodan's former neighbours in [[Vișina,_Dâmbovița|Vișina]]—which he still visited at the time—were generally antagonistic to Stan, calling Prodan a "quiet boy" and suggesting she probably deserved the beating.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kanald.ro/Vecinii-lui-Marcel-Prodan-DECLARATII-SOCANTE-Nu-batut-chiar-degeaba-Alexandra-VIDEO_2101.html|title=Vecinii lui Marcel Prodan, declaratii scoante: "Nu o fi batut-o chiar degeaba pe Alexandra"|trans-title=The neighbors of Marcel Prodan make scandalous confessions: "Alexandra Stan probably deserved the beating"|publisher=[[Kanal D]]|accessdate=3 January 2016|date=19 June 2013|language=Romanian}}</ref> In late 2013 Stan launched an anti-domestic violence campaign called ''"Nu bate! Mai bine cântă!"''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://stirileprotv.ro/stiri/actualitate/alexandra-stan-a-lansat-campania-impotriva-violentei-nu-bate-mai-bine-canta.html|title= Alexandra Stan a lansat campania impotriva violentei "Nu bate! Mai bine canta!"|trans-title=Alexandra Stan has released the campaign against violence "Don't beat! Sing!"|language=Romanian|publisher=''[[Pro TV|Știrile Pro TV]]''|accessdate=14 July 2016|date=13 November 2013}}</ref> Her 2014 song "[[Thanks for Leaving]]" alludes to her recovery from the violent incident with Prodan.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gandul.info/magazin/mesajul-alexandrei-stan-la-sfarsit-de-relatie-iti-multumesc-ca-ai-plecat-video-12539862|title=Mesajul Alexandrei Stan la sfârşit de relaţie: "Îţi mulţumesc că ai plecat".|publisher=[[Gândul]]|date=28 April 2014|language=Romanian|accessdate=2 September 2016|trans-title=Alexandra Stan's message at the end of her relationship: "Thanks for leaving".}}</ref><ref name="click">{{cite news|url=http://www.click.ro/comunitate/romanesti/alexandra-stan-rupe-tacerea-vezi-ce-spune-vedeta-despre-tragedia-prin-care|title=Alexandra Stan rupe tăcerea! Vezi ce spune vedeta despre tragedia prin care a trecut acum un an|publisher=Click!|date=28 April 2014|language=Romanian|accessdate=2 September 2016|trans-title=Alexandra Stan breaks the silence! See what the star says about the tragedy she went through a year ago}}</ref> Gheorghe Chelu of ''Click!'' magazine associated the title of Stan's 2017 single "[[9 Lives (Alexandra Stan song)|9 Lives]]" with the case, saying, "no trouble has ever managed to bring her down".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.click.ro/vedete/romanesti/alexandra-stan-are-9-vieti-ca-pisicile|title=Alexandra Stan are "9 vieti", ca pisicile|trans-title=Alexandra Stan has "9 lives", like the cats|language=Romanian|author=Chelu, Gheorghe|publisher=''Click!''|date=14 January 2017|accessdate=15 January 2017}}</ref>

revision.comment: Name is pronounced Djedi in all documentation, as it's derived from Djed (pillar)
revision.text:
{{about|the fictional magician|the robotic probe studying the pyramids|Djedi Project|the Orthodox Jewish singer|Dedi Graucher|the Israeli soccer player|Dedi Ben Dayan}} {{Infobox hieroglyphs |name = R11-R11-M17 |name explanation = Djedi
''D(j)dj'' Westcar-Papyrus, column 7, first row
''he who endures''Verena M. Lepper: ''Untersuchungen zu pWestcar. Eine philologische und literaturwissenschaftliche (Neu-)Analyse''. In: ''Ägyptologische Abhandlungen'', Band 70. Harrassowitz, Wiesbaden 2008, {{ISBN|3-447-05651-7}}, page 103. |}} '''Djedi''' (also '''Dedi''' or '''Djedi of Djed-Sneferu'''„Djed-Sneferu“ was the curatorial name of [[Dahshur]] during the Old Kingdom. See: Jean Claude Goyon, Christine Cardin: ''Proceedings of the ninth International Congress of Egyptologists'', volume 1. page 1128.) is the name of a [[fictional]] [[ancient Egypt]]ian [[magician (paranormal)|magician]] appearing in the fourth chapter of a story told in the legendary ''[[Westcar Papyrus]].'' He is said to have worked [[miracle|wonders]] during the reign of king ([[pharaoh]]) [[Khufu]] ([[Fourth dynasty of Egypt|4th Dynasty]]). ==Literary person== Djedi appears only in the fourth story of the ''Westcar Papyrus'' - there is no [[Archeology|archeological]] or [[History|historical]] evidence that he existed. Nevertheless he is an object of great interest for [[historian]]s and [[Egyptologist]]s, since his magic tricks are connected to later [[culture|cultural]] perceptions of the personality of king Khufu. Djedi is described as a [[commoner]] of extraordinary age, endowed with magical powers and talented in making [[prophecy|prophecies]].Alan B. Lloyd: ''Herodotus, book II: introduction'', Band 1. BRILL, Leiden 1975, {{ISBN|90-04-04179-6}}, page 104 – 106. ==The wonder of Djedi== According to the ''Westcar Papyrus,'' prince [[Djedefhor]] brings up the story of Djedi. He stands before his father, king Khufu, and says: “There is only speaking of miracles which happened a long time ago, something known by past generations only. Truth and falsehood cannot be distinguished here. But there is someone under thy majesty´s own lifetime who is not known, someone who is able to make a ignoramus become wise.” Khufu asks: “What's the meaning of this, Djedefhor, my son?” Djedefhor answers: “There's a commoner named ''Djedi'', living in Djed-Sneferu. He's a simple citizen, but 110 years old, eats 500 loaves of bread, a shoulder of [[beef]] and drinks 100 jars of [[beer]] every day. He is capable of resurrecting [[decapitation|decapitated]] beings. He is also said to be able to make wild [[lion]]s so obedient that the animal would follow him with a cord dragging on the ground. Furthermore, this Djedi has knowledge of the number of ''Iput''A word of unsure meaning which may be translated as "sealed chamber" or "sanctuary"; Egyptologists dispute the real meaning. See: Jenny Berggren: ''The Ipwt in Papyrus Westcar''. Master's Thesis, Uppsala 2006 ([https://web.archive.org/web/20070609172438/http://www.arkeologi.uu.se/egy/education/uppsatser/Berggren-Ipwt.pdf PDF; 2,57 MB]) in the ''wenet''-[[sanctuary]] of [[Thoth]].” The pharaoh spent a good deal of time to seek for these chambers, for he planned to build something similar to his horizon.In this case “horizon” is a quaint alteration for a royal [[cemetery]]. See: Verena M. Lepper: ''Untersuchungen zu pWestcar. Eine philologische und literaturwissenschaftliche (Neu-)Analyse''. In: ''Ägyptologische Abhandlungen'', Band 70. Harrassowitz, Wiesbaden 2008, {{ISBN|3-447-05651-7}}, page 42 & 114. And Khufu orders: “You thyself, Djedefhor, my son, may bring him to me!” And so Djedefhor arranges his journey during the first month of the ''schemu''-seasonEgyptian word for [[spring (season)|spring]]. See Rolf Krauss: ''Sothis- und Monddaten: Studien zur astronomischen und technischen Chronologie Altägyptens'', Gerstenberg, Hildesheim 1985, {{Listed Invalid ISBN|3-8067-8086-X}} and travels to Djed-Sneferu. He finds Djedi and invites the old man to the king's palace with the words: “Your condition is equal to someone who lives from aging and to someone who sleeps until dawn, free of illness and wheezing. For ‘aging’ is the time of dying, the time of the preparing the burial and the time of being buried. This is the questioning about the condition of a noble man. I have come to summon you in order of my father, justified, that you may eat from the delicacies my father gives, the food of his followers. And then he may guide you to the ancestors which are in the necropolis now.” Djedi replies: “Welcome, welcome, Djedefhor, son of the king, beloved of his father! May you be praised by your father, Khufu the justified. May he let your place be at the front of all time-honored ones. May thine ''[[Ka (Egyptian soul)|Ka]]'' successfully champion all things against any enemy. May thine ''[[Ba (Egyptian soul)|Ba]]'' know the ways that lead to the gateway of the mummified deceased.” Djedefhor brings Djedi to the harbor and makes a boat prepared for traveling. The old man promises to follow Djedefhor, on the condition that he may bring his books and scholars with him. Djedefhor accepts, and both men travel to Khufu's royal palace. Djedefhor enters the palace and goes immediately to his father, king Khufu. The prince says: “May thy majesty live, be blessed and being prosperous! I have brought Djedi to you!” Khufu replies: “Go and bring him to me!” Then Khufu takes place in the royal audience-hall. The Pharaoh receives Djedi with the words: “What is it, Djedi, this denying to have seen you ever before?” Djedi answers: “Oh sovereign, my lord! Only the one who is summoned is one who will come. I was summoned, and now see, oh sovereign, my lord, I have come.” The pharaoh continues: “Is it true, this talk-about that you could mend a severed head?” Djedi says: “Yes, oh sovereign, my lord. May you live, be blessed and prosperous. I know how to do that.” Khufu replies: “May a prisoner, who is jailed, be brought to me, so that his [[execution]] may be enforced.”. Djedi refuses with the words: “Not to make a human suffer, oh sovereign, my lord! May you live, be blessed and prosperous. You see, it was never allowed to do something like that on the noble flock.”It's assumed by Egyptologists, that the alteration “noble flock” was a bad pun to the human race in general. See: Verena M. Lepper: ''Untersuchungen zu pWestcar. Eine philologische und literaturwissenschaftliche (Neu-)Analyse''. In: ''Ägyptologische Abhandlungen'', Band 70. Harrassowitz, Wiesbaden 2008, {{ISBN|3-447-05651-7}}, page 42 & 114. Djedi chooses three animals instead - first a [[goose]]. He decapitates the goose and places her head at the eastern side of the audience hall, the body at the western side. Then Djedi utters a secret spell and the head of the goose stands up, starting to waddle. Then the body of the goose stands up and waddles, too. Both body-parts move into equal directions, then melt together. The resurrected goose now leaves the hall cackling. The same performance is done with an undefined water birdThe bird in question is called ''khet-aa-bird'' which means “the bird with long, wooden legs”. It is highly uncertain which race of bird was meant in the papyrus. Verena Lepper thinks about a [[Eurasian bittern]], which is mentioned in offering lists of the Old Kingdom. See: Verena M. Lepper: ''Untersuchungen zu pWestcar. Eine philologische und literaturwissenschaftliche (Neu-)Analyse''. In: ''Ägyptologische Abhandlungen'', Band 70. Harrassowitz, Wiesbaden 2008, {{ISBN|3-447-05651-7}}, page 115. and a [[bull]]. Both animals are brought successfully back to life, too. Now the king says: “It is said that you know the number of ''Iput'' inside the ''wenet''-sanctuary of Thoth. Now?” Djedi replies: “May you be praised, oh sovereign, my lord! I don't know their number. But I know where they can be found.” Khufu asks: “Where is it?” Djedi answers: “There is a box of scrolls, made of [[flint]], which is stored in a room called ‘archive’ at [[Heliopolis (Ancient Egypt)|Heliopolis]].” The king orders: “Take that box!” Djedi replies: “May your highness be prosperous and blessed, I'm not the one who can bring it to you.” Khufu asks: “Who may be the one who could bring it to me?” Djedi answers: “The eldest of the three children in the womb of ''[[Rededjet]]'', he will bring it to you.” The king says: “I really wish all these things you say. Who is it, this ''Rededjet''?” Djedi replies: “It's the wife of a ''wab''-priest of the god [[Ra]], lord of [[Sachebu]]. The god has adumbrated, that the eldest of the three shall worship as a high priest of Heliopolis over the whole realm.” The king's mood becomes grim after this. Djedi asks: “What is that heart of thine, oh sovereign, my lord, becoming so sad! Is it because of the children I have adumbrated? First your son, then his son and then one of them.” Khufu replies: “When will this Rededjet give birth?” Djedi says: “It will happen during the first month of the ''peret''-season,Ancient Egyptian name of the winter season. See: Verena M. Lepper: ''Untersuchungen zu pWestcar. Eine philologische und literaturwissenschaftliche (Neu-)Analyse''. In: ''Ägyptologische Abhandlungen'', Band 70. Harrassowitz, Wiesbaden 2008, {{ISBN|3-447-05651-7}}, page 116. on the fifteenth day.″ Khufu becomes indignant: “But it's when the canal-of-two-[[Mugilidae]]Ancient Egyptian name of the [[Nile]]. See: Verena M. Lepper: ''Untersuchungen zu pWestcar. Eine philologische und literaturwissenschaftliche (Neu-)Analyse''. In: ''Ägyptologische Abhandlungen'', Band 70. Harrassowitz, Wiesbaden 2008, {{ISBN|3-447-05651-7}}, page 116. is cut off!? I would even work with my very own hands to enter them! And then I will visit that temple of Ra, lord of Sachebu.” And Djedi says: “Then I will make the waters at the fordable spots of the canal-of-two-Mugilidae become four cubits in height for you.” Khufu stands up and orders: “Have Djedi assigned to a place within the palace of my son Djedefhor where he shall live from now on. His daily gainings be 1000 loaves of bread, 100 jars of beer, one neat and 100 bundles of [[field garlic]].” And all things are done as ordered.Verena M. Lepper: ''Untersuchungen zu pWestcar. Eine philologische und literaturwissenschaftliche (Neu-)Analyse''. In: ''Ägyptologische Abhandlungen'', Band 70. Harrassowitz, Wiesbaden 2008, {{ISBN|3-447-05651-7}}, page 41 – 47, 103 & 308 – 310..Miriam Lichtheim: ''Ancient Egyptian literature: a book of readings. The Old and Middle Kingdoms'', Band 1. University of California Press 2000, {{ISBN|0-520-02899-6}}, page 215 – 220.Adolf Erman: ''Die Märchen des Papyrus Westcar I. Einleitung und Commentar''. In: ''Mitteilungen aus den Orientalischen Sammlungen''. Heft V, Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Berlin 1890. page 10 – 12. ==Modern analysis== Historians and Egyptologists such as [[Adolf Erman]] and [[Kurt Heinrich Sethe]] once thought the tales of ''Westcar Papyrus'' were mere [[folklore]]. Magical tricks that show animals being decapitated and their heads being replaced were performed as recently as a few decades ago, though today they are rarely shown because of [[aesthetic]]al and [[ethic]]al misgivings.Udo Bartsch: ''Unterhaltungskunst A-Z (Taschenbuch der Künste)''. Henschel, Leipzig 1977 (2. Ausgabe), page 85. Modern Egyptologists like {{ill|Verena Lepper|de}} and [[Miriam Lichtheim]] deny this view and they argue that Sethe and Erman may have just failed to see the profundity of such novels. They point to multiple similar but somewhat later ancient Egyptian writings in which magicians perform very similar magic tricks and make prophecies to a king. According to Lepper and Lichtheim, their stories are obviously inspired by the tale of Djedi. Descriptive examples are the papyri ''pAthen'' and ''The prophecy of Neferti''. These [[novel]]s show how popular the theme of prophesying already was during the [[Old Kingdom of Egypt|Old Kingdom]] - just like in the story of the ''Westcar Papyrus.'' And they both talk about subalterns with magical powers similar to those of Djedi's. The Papyrus ''pBerlin 3023'' contains the novel ''The Eloquent Peasant'', in which the following [[phrase]] appears: “See, these are artists who create the existing anew, who even replace a severed head”, which can be interpreted as an allusion to the ''Westcar Papyrus.'' ''pBerlin 3023'' contains another reference which strengthens the idea that many ancient Egyptian novels were influenced by ''Westcar Papyrus'': column 232 contains the phrase ''sleeping until dawn'', which appears nearly word-by-word in the ''Westcar Papyrus.'' Since ''pAthen'', ''pBerlin 3023'' and ''The prophecy of Neferti'' show the same manner of speaking and equal picking up quaint phrases, Lepper and Lichtheim hold that Djedi (and the other wise men from same papyrus) must have been known to Egyptian authors for a long time. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.cs.st-andrews.ac.uk/~mjn/egyptian/texts/corpus/pdf/Westcar.pdf Transcription and translating of Papyrus Westcar (Berlin Papyrus 3033) into English by the transcription of A. M. Blackman (1988)] (PDF-File) *[http://www.reshafim.org.il/ad/egypt/texts/westcar_papyrus.htm Djedi in Papyrus Westcar at ''reshafim.org''] {{Ancient Egyptian religion footer|collapsed}} [[Category:African folklore]] [[Category:Ancient Egyptian literature]] [[Category:Folklore characters]]

{{italic title}} The '''''Encyclopædia Edinensis''''' was a six-volume general [[encyclopedia]] published in [[Edinburgh]] in 1827, and intended for a popular audience. It was edited by [[James Millar (physician)|James Millar]], who died just before it was complete.<ref name="Miller2004">{{cite book|author=David Philip Miller|title=Discovering Water: James Watt, Henry Cavendish, and the Nineteenth Century 'Water Controversy'|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=orL4QRlvBfYC&pg=PA72|accessdate=19 May 2012|year=2004|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-0-7546-3177-4|page=72}}</ref>
==Editorial staff== *James Millar, principal editor *[[Jeremiah Kirby]] and [[Richard Poole (physician)|Richard Poole]], main editors and contributors.<ref name="EE">James Millar, ''Encyclopedia Edinensis; or, Dictionary of arts, sciences, and literature'' vol. 1 (1827), p. vi; [https://archive.org/stream/encyclopediaedin01millrich#page/vi/mode/2up archive.org].</ref> Poole wrote articles on "[[Mental disease|Mental Diseases]]".<ref name="The Journal of psychological medicine and mental pathology">{{cite book|title=The Journal of psychological medicine and mental pathology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PfIEAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA157|accessdate=19 May 2012|year=1851|publisher=Churchill|page=157}}</ref> *[[John Sommers]], minister at [[Falkirk]], was proprietor and also editor for the last three volumes.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Scotland|author2=Society for the Benefit of the Sons and Daughters of the Clergy|title=The new statistical account of Scotland|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Dn0LAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA369|accessdate=20 May 2012|year=1845|publisher=W. Blackwood and Sons|page=369}}</ref>
Work began on the ''Encyclopædia'' in 1816.<ref>S. Padraig Walsh ''Anglo-American general encyclopedias 1703-1967'' New York and London; R.R. Bowser Company 1968 p.55</ref> Millar edited the fourth and parted of the fifth editions of the ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]'' and had contributed extensively to both. His goal with the Edinensis was to create a more popular work. However, his use of a large [[Quarto (binding)|quarto format]], reminiscent of the ''Britannica'' hampered the project as [[duodecimal]], miniature formats were then in vogue.<ref>Robert Collison ''Encyclopedias: their history throughout the ages'' 2nd ed. New York and London; Haffner Publishing Company 1966 p.178</ref>
== Phrenology ==
The editorial line was quite sympathetic to [[phrenology]]. According to the ''[[Phrenological Journal]]'', Sommers approved the inclusion of the uncritical article "Phrenology".<ref>{{cite book|title=The phrenological journal and miscellany|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MrQ6AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA641|accessdate=20 May 2012|year=1824|publisher=s.n.|pages=641–3}}</ref> Poole in 1819 wrote for the encyclopedia an article on [[education]], an early treatment from the point of phrenology.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Phrenological journal and miscellany|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cA3tN3ttpOYC&pg=PA171|accessdate=20 May 2012|year=1826|publisher=Printed for the Proprietors|page=171}}</ref>
==Other contributors== *[[John Adamson of Newton]] *[[Alexander Anderson (Encyclopædia Edinensis contributor)|Alexander Anderson]], [[Polar Expeditions]] etc. *[[George Buchanan (engineer born 1790)|George Buchanan]], Astronomy and Dialling *[[James Couper (astronomer)|James Couper]] *[[John Dick (minister)|John Dick]] [[M.D.]], [[Midwifery]] *[[Alexander Duncan (Encyclopædia Edinensis contributor)|Alexander Duncan]], [[Miracle]] etc. *[[James Flint (Encyclopædia Edinensis contributor)|James Flint]] *[[William Galbraith (mathematician)|William Galbraith]], Navigation *[[Patrick Gibson (artist)|Patrick Gibson]], design *Rev. [[David Liston]], [[Calcutta]], [[Mechanics]] *[[Henry Liston]], Music *[[Robert Macmillan]] *[[Lockhart Muirhead]] *Rev. [[Thomas Nelson (Encyclopædia Edinensis contributor)|Thomas Nelson]], [[Religion]] *[[Alexander Peterkin]] *[[Rev. Dr. Russel]] of [[Leith]], [[Magnetism]] and [[Meteorology]] *[[John Sommers (minister)|John Sommers]] *[[Walter Tod]], Theology etc. *[[John Wallace (Encyclopædia Edinensis contributor)|John Wallace]] *[[Robert Wallace (mathematician)|Robert Wallace]].<ref name="EE"/>

*''[https://archive.org/details/encyclopediaedin02millrich Encyclopedia Edinensis; or, Dictionary of arts, sciences, and literature]'' Vol. 2

revision.comment: Not a trusted external site in seeking further information.
revision.text:
{{for|the dialogue by Lucian|Amores (Lucian)}} [[File:Eros-piccadilly-circus.jpg|thumb|''Anteros'', popularly called ''Eros'', by [[Alfred Gilbert]], 1885; from the Shaftesbury Memorial in [[Piccadilly Circus]].]]
The '''Erotes''' ({{IPAc-en|ə|ˈ|r|oʊ|t|iː|z}}) are a collective of winged gods associated with love and sexual intercourse in [[Greek mythology]]. They are part of [[Aphrodite]]'s [[retinue]]. ''Erotes'' (Greek {{lang|grc|ἔρωτες}}) is the plural of ''[[Eros]]'' ("Love, Desire"), who as a singular deity has a more complex mythology.
Other named Erotes are [[Anteros]] ("Love Returned"),<ref>Emma Stafford, "From the Gymnasium to the Wedding: Eros in Athenian Art and Cult," in ''Erôs in Ancient Greece'' (Oxford University Press, 2013), p. 196.</ref> [[Himeros]] ("Impetuous Love" or "Pressing Desire"), [[Hedylogos]] ("Sweet-talk"), [[Hymenaios]] ("Bridal-Hymn"), [[Hermaphroditus]] ("Hermaphrodite" or "Effeminate"), and [[#Pothos|Pothos]] ("Desire, Longing," especially for one who is absent).<ref>Claude Calame, ''The Poetics of Eros in Ancient Greece'' (Princeton University Press, 1999, originally published 1992 in Italian), pp. 30–32.</ref>
The Erotes became a motif of [[Hellenistic art]], and may appear in [[Roman art]] in the alternate form of multiple [[Cupid]]s or [[Cupid and Psyche|Cupids and Psyches]]. In the [[classical tradition|later tradition]] of [[Western art]], erotes become indistinguishable from figures also known as Cupids, amorini, or amoretti.<ref>John Ferguson, ''The Religions of the Roman Empire'' (Cornell University Press, 1970), p. 145; Leonard Barkan, ''Unearthing the Past: Archaeology and Aesthetics in the Making of Renaissance Culture'' (Yale University Press, 1999), p. 138.</ref>
==General role and attributes== {{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 240 | footer = | image1 = Hermaphroditus and Erotes. Onyx. 1st century B.C..jpg | alt1 = | caption1 =[[Hermaphroditos]] and the erotes, onyx cameo from [[Alexandria]], 1st century BCE. Detailed image below in an engraving. | image2 = Ermafrodito e amorini.JPG | alt2 = | caption2 = }} The erotes are a group of winged gods in Classical mythology. They are associated with love and sexual desire, and form part of Aphrodite's retinue. The individual erotes are sometimes linked to particular aspects of love, and are often associated with same-sex desire.<ref name=conner64>Conner, p. 64, "Aphrodite"</ref><ref name=connererot>Conner, p. 133, "Erotes"</ref><ref name=connereros>Conner, p. 132, "Eros"</ref><ref name=connerpoth>Conner, p.270, "Pothos"</ref> Sometimes the erotes are regarded as manifestations of a singular god, [[Eros]].<ref>Younger, p. 45, "Eros/Cupid)</ref>
Stories of the erotes' [[mischief]] or [[prank]]s were a popular theme in Hellenistic culture, particularly in the 2nd century BCE.<ref>Strong, p. 265</ref> Spells to attract or repel erotes were used, in order to induce love or the opposite.<ref>Collins, pp. 100, 167.</ref> Different erotes represented various facets of love or desire, such as [[unrequited love]] (Himeros), mutual love (Anteros) or longing (Pothos).<ref name=connererot/>
The erotes were usually portrayed as [[nude]], handsome, winged youths.<ref name=connererot/> The earliest known sculptured [[frieze]]s depicting a group of erotes and winged maidens driving chariots pulled by [[goat]]s, were created to decorate [[theatre]]s in ancient Greece in the 2nd century BCE.<ref>Sturgeon, p. 124–25.</ref> The representation of erotes in such friezes became common, including erotes in [[hunting]] scenes.<ref>Sturgeon, p. 126</ref> Due to their role in the classical mythological pantheon, the erotes' representation is sometimes purely [[symbol]]ic (indicating some form of love) or they may be portrayed as individual characters.<ref name=amoungwom>Rabinowitz & Auanger, p. 239.</ref> The presence of erotes in otherwise non-sexual images, such as of two women, has been interpreted to indicate a homoerotic subtext.<ref name=amoungwom/> In the cult of Aphrodite in [[Anatolia]], [[Iconography|iconographic]] images of the goddess with three erotes symbolized the three realms over which she had dominion: the Earth, sky, and water.<ref>Ridgway, p. 115</ref>
== Retinue Members== Groups of numerous erotes are portrayed in ancient Greek and [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] art. In addition, a number of named gods have been regarded as erotes, sometimes being assigned particular associations with aspects of love.
===Anteros=== {{main article| Anteros}}
[[Anteros]] (Greek: Ἀντέρως, ''Antérōs'') was the god of requited love, literally "love returned" or "counterpart love". He punished those who scorned love and the advances of others, and was the avenger of unrequited love.<ref>Evans, p. 20</ref> Anteros was the son of Ares and Aphrodite in [[Greek mythology]], and given to his brother Eros as a playmate because the latter was lonely. In another version, Anteros arose from mutual feelings between [[Poseidon]] and [[Nerites (mythology)|Nerites]].<ref>[[Claudius Aelianus|Aelian]], ''On Animals'', 14. 28</ref> Physically, Anteros was depicted as similar to Eros in every way, though sometimes with longer hair and butterfly wings.{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}} He has been described as armed with either a [[gold]]en club or arrows of [[lead]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}}
===Eros=== {{main article|Eros}} [[File:Eros bobbin Louvre CA1798.jpg|thumb|[[Eros]]. Attic red-figure bobbin, ca. 470–450 BCE.]] Originally, [[Eros]] was the god of [[love]] and [[sexual intercourse|intercourse]]; he was also worshiped as a [[fertility]] deity. His [[Roman mythology|Roman]] counterpart was [[Cupid]] (desire).
In later myths, he was the son of the deities Aphrodite and [[Ares]]: it is the Eros of these later myths who is one of the erotes. Eros was associated with athleticism, with statues erected in ''[[Gymnasium (ancient Greece)|gymnasia]]'',<ref name=connereros/> and "was often regarded as the protector of homosexual love between men."<ref name=connereros/> Eros was depicted as often carrying a [[lyre]] or bow and arrow. He was also depicted accompanied by [[dolphin]]s, [[flute]]s, [[rooster]]s, [[rose]]s, and [[torch]]es.<ref name=connereros/>
===Hedylogos=== {{main article| Hedylogos}}
[[Hedylogos]] or Hedylogus ({{lang-grc|Ἡδυλογος}}) was the god of [[wikt:sweet-talk|sweet-talk]] and [[flattery]]. He is not mentioned in any existing literature, but he is depicted on [[Pottery of ancient Greece|ancient Greek vase paintings]].
===Hermaphroditus=== {{main article| Hermaphroditus}}
[[Hermaphroditus]] was the god of hermaphrodites and of effeminate men. He was the son of [[Hermes]] and [[Aphrodite]]. Born a remarkably handsome boy but after the [[water nymph]] [[Salmacis]] fell in love with him and she prayed to be united forever, their two forms merged into one.
===Himeros=== Himeros (Greek: {{lang|grc|Ἵμερος}} "uncontrollable desire", Latin: ''Himerus'') represented desire and unrequited love.<ref name=younger40>Younger, p. 40, "Desire"</ref> Himeros was identified by his carrying a ''[[Tainia (costume)|taenia]]'', a colourful headband worn by athletes.<ref>Conner, p. 178, ''Himerus''</ref> He is described in [[Theogony|Hesiod's Theogony]] as being born alongside Aphrodite.
===Hymenaeus/Hymen=== {{main article|Hymen (god)}}
[[Hymen (god)|Hymenaeus]] ({{lang-el|Ὑμεναιος}}) or Hymen ({{lang-el|Ὑμην}}) was the god of weddings, marriage, and the bridal hymn.
===Pothos=== [[File:Pothos Via Cavour Musei Capitolini MC2417 n1.jpg|thumb|upright|Statue of Pothos at the Centrale Montemartini]] Pothos (Greek: {{lang|grc|Πόθος}} "yearning") was one of [[Aphrodite]]'s erotes and brother to Himeros and Eros. In some versions of myth, Pothos is the son of Eros, or is portrayed as an independent aspect of him.<ref name=connererot/> Yet others called him son of [[Zephyrus]] and [[Iris (mythology)|Iris]].<ref>[[Nonnus]], ''Dionysiaca'', 47. 340</ref> He was part of Aphrodite's retinue, and carried a vine, indicating a connection to wine or the god [[Dionysus]]. Pothos represents longing or yearning.<ref name=younger40/> In the temple of [[Aphrodite]] at [[Megara]], there was a sculpture that represented Pothos together with [[Eros]] and Himeros which has been credited to [[Scopas]].<ref>Pausanias, Description of Greece 1. 43. 6</ref> Pothos is a name for the white [[Asphodelus albus]] flower, "used at funerals" according to [[Arthur Hort]]'s index and translation of [[Theophrastus]] (VI, 8, 3).<ref>https://archive.org/details/enquiryintoplant02theouoft</ref>
==See also== *[[Cupidon (disambiguation)|Cupidon]] *[[List of love and lust deities]] *[[LGBT themes in mythology]] *[[Harmonia (mythology)|Harmonia]]
